msItem.author: Thomas Hoccleve
msItem.title: Letter of Cupid
msItem.incipit:
To hire name ȝhit is it no reprefe
ffor all to vertu was þat she wrowght
msItem.explicit:
The yeer of grace ioyfull and iocound
A thowsande foure hundrede the secunde
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit littera Cupidinis directa
Subditis suis Amatoribus

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: The Pain and Sorrow of Evil Marriage
msItem.incipit:
Glory vnto God laude and benysow
To Iohn to Petir & also to Laurence
msItem.explicit:
Wherfore yonge menne, to eschewe sorowe & care
Withdrawe your foot or ye ffall in the snare

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Examples against Women
msItem.incipit:
TO Adam and Eve Crist gave the soueraigte
Of Paradice and domynacioun
msItem.explicit:
Some renne in riote of custome this is no faile
Suche woll disceyue there nature is so frayle

msItem.author: Peter Idley
msItem.title: Instructions to his Son
msItem.rubric: Incinium mei tractus sit nomine domine mei Ihesu Christi a quo
msItem.incipit:
In the begynnyng of this litle werke
I pray god my penne to lede
msItem.explicit:
Safe only nature þe which doth me spede
To the my Childe to þis simple dede

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: A Complaynt of the Black Knight
msItem.incipit:
IN May whanne fflora the lusty Quene
The soill hath cladde in grene rede and whight
msItem.explicit:
Exiled be that I may not atteyne
Resoun to ffynde of myne aduersite

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Anelida and Arcite
msItem.incipit:
O Thowe fers god of armes mars the rede
That in thy ffrosty Cuntre called Trace
msItem.explicit:
With in the Temple with a sorowfull chere
That Shapyn was as ye shall aftir here

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Parliament of Fowls
msItem.incipit:
The life so short the crafte so longe to lerne
The assay so harde so sharpe the conqueryng
msItem.explicit:
That I shall mete some thyng for to fare
The bettir and thus to rede I woll not spare
msItem.finalRubric:
Explicit
Here endith the parlement of ffowlis

msItem.author: John Lydgate
msItem.title: Fall of Princes
msItem.rubric:
Where Bochas repreuyth hemme þat yeue
hasti credence to euery report or tale
msItem.incipit:
All though so be in euery maner Age
ffolkis been dyuers of Condicions
msItem.explicit:
Bothe circumspect not hasty but prudent
And yeuyth no credence without auysement
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit expliceat vio ludere scriptor eat

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Troilus and Criseyde
msItem.incipit:
The dowbill sorowe off Troilous to tell
That was the kyng Priamus sone of Troy
msItem.explicit:
Vs lakkis nought but þat we witt wolde
A certeyn houre in which she come sholde

support.watermark: Fols. 1-17 ‘Armoires-Pal’ (Briquet, 2064), fols. 18-53 ‘Armoires-Trois Fleurs de Lis’ (similar to Briquet, 1725), fols. 54-93 ‘Anneau’ (similar to Briquet, 689).

supportDesc.extent: ii (modern endleaves) + 93 + ii (modern endleaves, foliated 94-95) c. 280 200
supportDesc.foliation: Flyleaves unnumbered. The manuscript has been foliated twice: firstly, an older ink foliation which numbers every tenth folio and the last folio, regularly inconsistent by 5 folios; secondly, a modern pencil foliation which numbers fols. 1–93 correctly and emends the older ink foliation. There are catchwords on fols. 17v and 35v only.
supportDesc.collation: 118-1 (fols. 1-17; first cancelled), 220, 32, 416-2 (14 folios, fifteenth and sixteenth cancelled), 524, 68-6 (2 folios, second, third, fourth, fifth, seventh, and eighth cancelled), 714. Collation following D. W. Mosser, A new collation for Bodleian Digby MS 181, Papers of the Bibliographical Society of America, 82 (1988), 604-11.
supportDesc.condition: Front board detached. Some pages affected by damp in the lower and upper margins. Significant staining in the first quire and at the break between quires 1 and 2. Occasional tears.

layoutDesc.layout: Frame ruled in ink (faded). Fols. 1-53 contain 15-44 lines, in predominantly 6 stanzas. 190 100
Frame ruled in ink (faded). Fols. 54-93 contain 38-42 lines. 190 100

handDesc.handNote: The manuscript was copied by 2 hands of the fifteenth century in a mixture of secretary and anglicana graphs. The first hand is responsible for fols. 1-53v, and the second for fols. 54r-93v. The change in hand at folio 53 coincides with a change in paper. Daniel W. Mosser identifies the first scribe as John Brode, whose hand also appears in John Rylands Library, MS English 113 (copied c.1475-1500). Brode may also be responsible for the anadrome explicit Edorb quod on folio 39r (see Daniel W. Mosser, The Scribe of Chaucer Manuscripts Rylands English 113 and Bodleian Digby 18, Manuscripta, 34 (1990), 129-47).

decoDesc.decoNote: Spaces (of 2-7 lines) left for initials at the beginnings of texts and textual units: fols. 7r, 10v, 31r, 39v, 44r, 52r, 54r, 59r, 68r, 69r, 86v, and 87v – all undecorated.
Occasionally, but inconsistently, the first initial of the leaf is flourished.

physDesc.additions: Owner's inscriptions on , , and Contemporary note in lower left margin of folio 6r, trimmed.

bindingDesc.p: Bound in Digby brown leather c. 1632-4.

history.provenance: Inscribed, Peter Idywerte, 000 century (first parchment flyleaf, previously a pastedown).
93v John [ ]pper visible under UV light (see Michael C. Seymour, The manuscripts of Chaucer's Troilus, Scriptorium, 46:1 (1992) ).
Kenelm Digby, 1603–1665: inscribed, Vindica te tibi Kenelme Digby (fol. 1r).

recordHist.source: Description by Charlotte Ross (September 2022). Formerly described in the Quarto Catalogue (W. D. Macray, Bodleian Library Quarto Catalogues IX: Digby Manuscripts, repr. with addenda by R. W. Hunt and A. G. Watson, 1999). Quarto Catalogue, cols. 193–4 Quarto Catalogue (addenda), p. 83 Quarto Catalogue (addenda), p. 84 Summary Catalogue, vol. 2, part 1, p. 75

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: Michael Seymour, A Catalogue of Chaucer Manuscripts, vol.I (Aldershot, 1995), 30-1
Daniel W. Mosser, The Scribe of Chaucer Manuscripts Rylands English 113 and Bodleian Digby 181, Manuscripta, 34 (1990), 129-47
